name: Connla of the Golden Hair

attributes.attribute: son of Conn of the Hundred Battles
met a woman of the Fairy race
traveled with her to her land
was offered eternal life and pleasure
was never seen again on this earth

sources: Cross, Tom Peete, and Clark Harris Slover, eds. Ancient Irish Tales. (New York: Henry Holt and Co., 1936), 488.
Hull, Eleanor. The Cuchullin Saga in Irish Literature. (London: David Nutt, 1898), 79.
Joyce, P. W. Ancient Celtic Romances. London: Parkgate Books, 1997, 106+.
Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: Connla, the son of Conn of the Hundred Battles and also known as Connla of the Golden Hair, was uninterested in earthly power after his encounter with a woman from the Fairy race on the mystical Uisneach Hill. As recorded in the Adventures of Connla, he chose to journey with her to her land where the offer of eternal life and pleasure was made to him. After that, he was never seen again on earth. For further information on this tale, refer to Fairy Lover.
